content.raw: @peter_mitrano just showed me that this is not compiling in Windows because of `this->nsInSec` inside `static_cast`, I'll make a pull request fixing it soon.
content.html: @peter_mitrano just showed me that this is not compiling in Windows because of this->nsInSec inside static_cast, I'll make a pull request fixing it soon.

update.description:
While working on the log playback tool, I felt the need for a global and versatile function to format time. In fact, there are variants implemented in several places, so I think it's a good idea to have it in a common place.

Added `Time::FormattedString` with the option to show/hide different elements (day, hour, min, sec, msec). Note that there's already a `Time::GetWallTimeAsISOString`, which uses a slightly different format.

Removed `TimePanel::FormatTime`, `TimerGUIPlugin::FormatTime` and `RestWebPlugin::FormatTime`, which were all doing similar things, and used the new function instead.
update.title: Move FormatTime to Time class

While working on the log playback tool, I felt the need for a global and versatile function to format time. In fact, there are variants implemented in several places, so I think it's a good idea to have it in a common place.

Added `Time::FormattedString` with the option to show/hide different elements (day, hour, min, sec, msec). Note that there's already a `Time::GetWallTimeAsISOString`, which uses a slightly different format.

content.html:
In pull request #1594, I fixed some clang warnings complaining about using the integer abs() with floating point values. This was happening because all literal constants expressed in scientific notation are interpreted as floating point values.

So to be safe, we should usually stay away from using scientific notation with our integer-based time class. A workaround is to declare constants like const int32_t nsInSec = 1000000000; or const int32_t nsInMs = 1000000; so we can be sure that integer math is used. In this case:

const int32_t nsInMs = 1000000;
msec = this->nsec / nsInMs;

content.raw:
Thanks for the tip. I did a quick search and found a couple of functions which output textual time, but neither seems to support `ms` out of the box (maybe they can display seconds with decimals though). I feel like it would take me some time to adapt the current implementation, and this is holding other pull requests related to logging.

Nevertheless, this seems to be very helpful, I should have looked into it before implementing this whole thing. If you don't mind, I'll keep it the way it is and maybe revisit this later.

* [ctime](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/chrono/c/ctime)

* [strftime](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/chrono/c/strftime)
content.html:
Thanks for the tip. I did a quick search and found a couple of functions which output textual time, but neither seems to support ms out of the box (maybe they can display seconds with decimals though). I feel like it would take me some time to adapt the current implementation, and this is holding other pull requests related to logging.

Nevertheless, this seems to be very helpful, I should have looked into it before implementing this whole thing. If you don't mind, I'll keep it the way it is and maybe revisit this later.

  • ctime

  • strftime

Ignore this if it's not useful.

content.raw: yay for reducing code duplication!
content.html: yay for reducing code duplication!

Using int as an input is a little confusing at first. I wonder if you could make it more readable with an enum:

enum FormatOption {DAYS = 0, HOURS = 1, MINUTES = 2, SECONDS = 3, MILLISECONDS = 4};

std::string FormattedString(FormatOption _start = 0, FormatOption _end = 4) const;

or something like that.

content.raw:
I think this call is a little confusing. Imagine a duration of 3600 seconds.

I would expect that Time::FormattedString(false, false, false, false, true, true) would look like this: "3600.000". 
However it looks like it comes out as "00.000", because the days, hours, minutes are always removed.

check out my branch format_time_seconds for this failing test.

check out my branch format_time_seconds for this failing test.
